Otherwise you probably want to preallocate the list with the number of items you want it to contain, as others have shown.

If you want a list that will automatically extend to fill in missing values, such that a[100] = value will work even if the list only has 50 items, this can be done with a custom __setitem__() method on a list subclass:

code:
class expandinglist(list):
    def __setitem__(self, index, value):
        length = len(self)
        if index < length:
            list.__setitem__(self, index, value)
        elif index = length:     # you don't actually need this case, it's just a bit
            self.append(value)   # faster than the below for adding a single item
        else:
            self.extend(([0] * (index - length)) + [value])

lyst = expandinglist()
lyst[5] = 5
print lyst
